Basal nuclei lesions



Damage to the basal nuclei disrupts action selection.
This can result in:

Difficulty initiating movement

Excessive or involuntary movements


Strength is usually preserved.




Basal nuclei dysfunction in Parkinsonian disorders leads to:

Bradykinesia

Rigidity

Resting tremor


Movement is difficult to initiate, not to execute.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A core problem


At any moment, the brain faces multiple possibilities. It must decide:

What is important

What can be ignored

What requires action


Emotion and motivation solve this problem.








Emotion and motivation are tightly linked. Both contribute to:

Prioritizing information

Biasing decisions

Driving behavior

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A functional definition of emotion
Emotion can be defined as:
A coordinated brain-body state that assigns value to a situation and prepares action. The terms emotion and feeling are often used interchangeably. In neuroscience, they refer to related but distinct processes.



Emotions are objective physiological and neural states.

Brain circuits

Bodily responses

Action tendencies

Occur without conscious awareness




Feelings are the subjective experience of emotional states. They reflect:

Awareness of bodily changes

Cognitive interpretation

Context and memory

Require consciousness

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A functional definition of emotion


Emotional responses are generated subcortically.
Feelings depend more strongly on cortical processing.
Emotions typically occur first. Feelings emerge later, if at all.


You can have:

Emotions without feelings

But not feelings without emotions







This distinction explains why:

We can react before we know why

Emotional behavior can precede awareness

Regulation can target feelings but not initial emotional responses

The brain acts before the mind explains.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A functional definition of motivation


Motivation is the inner drive that initiates, guides, and sustains goal-directed behavior Motivation refers to processes that:

Direct action toward goals

Sustain effort over time

Motivation answers the question:
Why act at all?


Emotion and motivation interact
Together, they determine:

What is pursued

What is avoided

How strongly we act


Emotional value influences motivation. Motivational state shapes emotional responses.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: Brain networks for emotion and feeling
text:
Brain networks for emotion and feeling


There is no single “emotion center”.

Several brain regions are consistently involved in emotion-related processes:

Amygdala

Hypothalamus

Brainstem nuclei

Insular cortex
Prefrontal cortex

Each contributes a specific computation.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: Brain networks for emotion and feeling
text:
Brain networks for emotion and feeling



Subcortical regions contribute to rapid and automatic responses.
They are involved in:

Detecting relevance

Generating physiological changes

Initiating action tendencies

These processes can occur without awareness.



Cortical regions contribute to:

Interpretation of emotional states

Contextual modulation

Regulation and control

Subjective experience

They shape how emotions are experienced as feelings.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A closer look: the amygdala


The amygdala is a key structure in emotional processing (generally fear). It is located in the medial temporal lobe. It is involved in detecting biologically relevant stimuli.

The amygdala contributes to:

Rapid evaluation of relevance

Detection of potential threat

Assigning emotional significance

It responds to both positive and negative stimuli. Amygdala responses are fast. They can occur before detailed cortical analysis.



Through its connections, the amygdala can:

Influence autonomic responses

Bias attention toward relevant stimuli

Modulate memory formation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A closer look: the amygdala


The amygdala is required for acquiring fear memories a process called fear conditioning.

Fear conditioning is a form of associative learning: It allows the organism to learn that a neutral stimulus predicts danger.


In a typical fear conditioning experiment:

A neutral stimulus is presented

An aversive stimulus follows

After repeated pairings, the neutral stimulus alone elicits a fear response.



The amygdala integrates:

Sensory information about the neutral stimulus

Information about the aversive outcome



A key distinction:

The amygdala is required for acquiring fear memories

It is also required for expressing conditioned fear

Damage to the amygdala disrupts both.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex
text:
A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex


Emotional responses are not fixed. They can be shaped, modulated, and regulated. A key role in this process is played by the prefrontal cortex.

Emotion regulation refers to processes that:

Modify emotional responses

Adjust their intensity or duration

Align emotions with goals and context

Regulation does not mean suppression.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Prefrontal subregions
Different prefrontal areas contribute differently:

Ventromedial prefrontal cortex
Value, emotional meaning, safety
Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Cognitive control and reappraisal
Orbitofrontal cortex
Outcome evaluation and updating

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex
text:
A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex


Different prefrontal subregions contribute differently:

Ventrolateral prefrontal cortex
Value, emotional meaning, safety
Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex
Cognitive control and reappraisal
Orbitofrontal cortex
Outcome evaluation and updating


One key regulatory strategy is reappraisal. Reappraisal involves:

Changing how a situation is interpreted

Altering emotional impact

This strategy strongly recruits prefrontal regions.








Prefrontal cortex regulates emotion through top-down control.
It can influence:

Amygdala activity

Autonomic responses

Behavioral expression

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Development matters
The prefrontal cortex matures slowly. Its structural and functional development continues beyond 20 years of age. This maturation timeline has important behavioral consequences.



During adolescence:

Subcortical emotion-related systems are largely matured

Emotional reactivity is strong

Prefrontal regulatory systems are still developing

Emotion generation is functional, regulation is not yet fully mature.








This creates a temporary imbalance:

Strong emotional and motivational signals

Weaker top-down regulatory control

This imbalance contributes to increased emotional intensity and risk-taking.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
A closer look: the amygdala



Fear conditioning can occur in two main forms:

Cued fear conditioning

Contextual fear conditioning




Fear conditioning relies on the association between:

Conditioned Stimulus (CS)
A previously neutral stimulus, such as a tone, a light or the context
Unconditioned Stimulus (US)
An inherently aversive stimulus, such as a mild foot shock





Cued fear conditioning procedure:
Training phase

The animal is placed in a familiar chamber

A CS (e.g. tone) is presented

The CS is paired with a US

During the test phase

The tone is presented alone

Often in a ‘different context’


If learning occurred, the CS alone elicits fear responses.

text:
A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex



Fear learning is not permanent and inflexible. Fear responses can be reduced when the threat is no longer present. This process is called fear extinction.


During extinction:

The conditioned stimulus (CS) is presented repeatedly

The unconditioned stimulus (US) is omitted

Over time, fear responses decrease. Extinction is a new form of learning.



Extinction does not erase the original fear memory. The CS-US association remains stored. Fear expression is modulated, not deleted.
Fear responses can reappear:

After time has passed

In a different context

After stress

This shows that the original memory persists.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex
text:
A closer look: the Prefrontal Cortex


During extinction:

Prefrontal cortex activity increases

Amygdala-driven fear responses decrease

This reflects top-down inhibitory control. In rodents, extinction depends strongly on the infralimbic cortex. The infralimbic cortex is considered homologous to ventromedial prefrontal regions in humans.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Wanting vs liking
Motivation is not identical to pleasure.
A key distinction:

[Wanting]
Drive to obtain an outcome
[Liking]
Pleasure experienced from the outcome

These processes can dissociate.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Neural systems for motivation



A key distinction:

Wanting: Drive to obtain an outcome
Liking: Pleasure experienced from the outcome

These processes can be dissociated.


Motivation depends on interactions between:

Cortical decision and control regions (Wanting)
Subcortical reward-related systems (Liking)

These systems bias action selection.



Dopamine plays a central role in motivation.
It is involved in:

Learning from outcomes

Predicting future rewards


Dopamine signals are not simple pleasure signals.

Two major dopaminergic pathways:

Mesolimbic pathway: Involved in reward prediction and reinforcement
Mesocortical pathway: Involved in decision-making, cognitive control, and goal maintenance

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text: Neural systems for motivation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Reward prediction



Motivational signals influence:

Basal nuclei and motor planning areas

Decision-making circuits

They bias which actions are selected and executed.


Dopamine neurons respond to:

Unexpected rewards

Cues that predict rewards

Over learning, activity shifts from outcome to predictor.
This supports adaptive behavior.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Reward prediction error



Dopamine neurons do not simply respond to rewards. They signal whether outcomes are better or worse than expected. This signal is called a reward prediction error.


A reward prediction error reflects the difference between:

Expected outcome

Actual outcome

This signal is used to update future behavior. Prediction error signals:

Update value representations
Bias future choices




Dopamine activity reflects prediction error:

Reward is better than expected: dopamine activity increases
Reward is as expected: little or no change
Reward is worse than expected or omitted: dopamine activity decreases

Learning occurs when expectations are violated. Over learning:

Dopamine responses shift from reward to predictive cues

The brain learns what predicts valuable outcomes

This supports adaptive, flexible behavior.

text:
What is stress



Stress is not an emotion. Stress is a physiological response to challenge or threat. It prepares the organism to cope with demands.


Stress refers to coordinated brain and body responses that:

Mobilize energy

Increase vigilance

Promote adaptive action

Stress is adaptive by design.



The body responds to stress through 2 major systems:

The autonomic nervous system

The hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis

These systems operate on different time scales.

Autonomic responses Fast, neural, seconds
HPA axis responses Slower, hormonal, minutes to hours

Both are coordinated but serve different functions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The HPA axis



The HPA axis is a hormonal stress response system. It links the brain to peripheral organs through endocrine signaling. It produces slower but longer-lasting effects than autonomic responses.

During stress:

The hypothalamus is activated (CRF)
The pituitary gland releases signaling hormones (ACTH)

The adrenal glands release glucocorticoids

This cascade is a loop.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cortisol and energy mobilization


Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol:

Increase glucose availability

Decrease sensitivity to pain
Modify immune and metabolic activity

They prepare the body for prolonged challenge.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: Brain control of the HPA axis
text:
Brain control of the HPA axis



Stress responses differ in duration.

Acute stress: Short-term, adaptive, protective
Chronic stress: Prolonged, costly, potentially damaging

The difference lies in regulation, not intensity.


The HPA axis is regulated by the brain. Key contributors include:

Amygdala

Prefrontal cortex

Hippocampus

Stress is not just peripheral.



Glucocorticoids act back on the brain. They signal when stress responses should be reduced. This negative feedback limits stress exposure.


If stress responses are not properly terminated:

Hormone levels remain elevated

Brain and body systems are altered

Chronic stress reflects dysregulation, not overreaction.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Autonomic responses in stress
During stress, the autonomic system (the sympathetic division) produces rapid effects:

Increased heart rate

Increased blood pressure

Faster breathing

Reduced digestion

These changes prepare the body for immediate action.

text:
What is Neuroplasticity


The ability of the brain, of nervous circuits, to change in response to experience is called neuroplasticity.


The effectiveness of synaptic connections is changed by experience.

Experience changes the circuit’s electrical activity and this modifies the synaptic effectiveness.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The complexity of the brain



100 billion neurons


Up to 1000 synaptic inputs on a single neuron


600 million connections/mm3


Our behavior, thoughts, actions, perception, ability to imagine or remember, depend on the coordinated activation of multiple nervous circuits, which may also include neurons located in different brain areas.



Genetics and individual experience:

Interact and together guide the development of behavior and of neural circuits supporting it
continue to interact throughout life, by guiding the plastic changes induced by experience in the brain and therefore in behavior, by shaping the way we “see” what surrounds us and the way we react to it.


Different experiences, different brains, different behaviors

text:
Neurodevelopment and neuroplasticity

How long does neurodevelopment take?

It doesn’t take 9 months. At birth, the human brain is still very immature.



29 days: there is a tube (neural tube)
59 days: has acquired a different morphology in the most anterior part (where the brain will appear)

70 days: the brain can be already recognized
6 months: there are no convolutions yet, there is not yet enough surface to fold it, it is smooth
9 months: it is still very immature.

Myelination - the axons are covered by myelin

Neurodevelopment and neuroplasticity

Gene specification has the role of guiding the initial processes of brain development and formation of neural connections.


The specific experience of the individual and his interactions with the environment have the role of guiding the final phases of the development of the brain circuits, leading them to the mature state and therefore guiding the development of the different expressions of behavior in an individual-specific way.


Different experiences, different brains, different behaviors

Synaptic Plasticity
Synaptic plasticity refers to changes in the effectiveness of communication
between a presynaptic neuron and one or more postsynaptic neurons. It can involve:

Functional

Changes in the efficacy of existing synaptic contacts

Structural

Formation of new synaptic contacts
(structural plasticity)
Elimination of existing synaptic contacts
(structural plasticity)





Adult Neurogenesis
Adult neurogenesis refers to the generation of new neurons
that integrate into pre-existing neural circuits.
It occurs only in specific brain structures:

Hippocampus
Olfactory bulb
Not in the cerebral cortex

The rules of Synaptic Plasticity

Not all changes in electrical activity induce plasticity phenomena in a neural circuit.


Hebb’s Principle
Hebb’s principle states that if a presynaptic neuron A repeatedly activates
a postsynaptic neuron B, the synaptic connection between A and B is strengthened
(1949).
A corollary of Hebb’s principle
If neuron A repeatedly fails to activate neuron B,
the synaptic connection between A and B is weakened.

Neurons that fire together, wire together.

Detecting correlated activity

A key molecular mechanism is the NMDA receptor. It is a glutamate receptor with special properties. It acts as a coincidence detector.


NMDA receptors require two conditions to be met:

Glutamate release from the presynaptic neuron

Depolarization of the postsynaptic membrane


At resting membrane potential the NMDA receptor channel is blocked by a magnesium ion. Glutamate alone is not sufficient to activate it.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Detecting correlated activity



During normal synaptic activity:

AMPA receptors open

Sodium enters the postsynaptic neuron

This produces fast excitatory synaptic transmission.


During correlated activity:

Presynaptic glutamate release occurs

Postsynaptic depolarization is sufficient

The magnesium block is removed and NMDA receptors now open.








Opening of NMDA receptors allows:

Calcium ions to enter the postsynaptic neuron

The most important effect is:

Insertion of additional AMPA receptors into the postsynaptic membrane

Long-term potentiation (LTP)
Long-term potentiation (LTP) is a persistent increase
in synaptic efficacy following correlated activity.

LTP is considered a cellular mechanism of learning and memory.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Effects of synaptic plasticity



One form of LTP is the functional modification of the synapse.
This involves:

Increased synaptic efficacy

Insertion of additional AMPA receptors

Enhanced postsynaptic responsiveness

This effect take place after few seconds after the triggering event.



LTP can also involve morphological modification of the synapse.
This includes:

Growth of dendritic spines

Enlargement of existing synapses

Formation of new synaptic contacts

Structural changes stabilize long-term modifications and take place after hours or days respect to the triggering event.

text:
Synaptic weakening



Hebbian plasticity has an important corollary. If presynaptic activity repeatedly fails to activate
the postsynaptic neuron, synapses can weaken.


Long-term depression (LTD) is a persistent decrease in synaptic efficacy.
Functional LTD involves:

Removal of AMPA receptors from the synapse

Reduced postsynaptic responsiveness

Transmission becomes less effective.



LTD can also produce morphological changes:

Shrinkage of dendritic spines

Elimination of synaptic contacts

This supports pruning and circuit refinement.


LTP and LTD operate together. They allow neural circuits to:

Strengthen relevant connections

Weaken irrelevant ones

Plasticity is about balance, not only growth.

text:
The instability problem



If Hebbian plasticity acted alone:

Highly active neurons would increase their firing indefinitely

Weakly active neurons would fall silent

Neural activity would become unbalanced.


This is incompatible with stable brain function. Unregulated Hebbian plasticity would lead to:

Runaway excitation in some circuits

Loss of activity in others

Learning would destroy, rather than preserve, network function.



The nervous system requires mechanisms that:

Stabilize overall activity

Prevent excessive excitation or depression

This principle is called homeostatic plasticity.


Homeostatic plasticity refers to mechanisms that maintain neural activity within a functional range.
It preserves the overall level of discharge of neurons and networks.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Homestatic plasticity



Homeostatic plasticity acts to stabilize:

Average firing rate

Synaptic input strength

Network excitability



When activity is chronically high:

Synaptic strengths are globally scaled down

When activity is chronically low:

Synaptic strengths are globally scaled up

Relative differences between synapses are preserved.



A key contrast:

Hebbian plasticity
Strengthens or weakens specific synapses
Homeostatic plasticity
Regulates overall activity levels

Both operate simultaneously.

Hippocampal neurogenesis


The richness of the environment affects neural plasticity
not only at synapses, but also at the level of cell generation.

This process is called adult neurogenesis.


Adult neurogenesis refers to the generation of new neurons
that integrate into pre-existing neural circuits.
For a long time, this was believed to occur only during development.
Adult neurons were considered a non-renewable population.



The presence of adult neurogenesis was demonstrated
by Fernando Nottebohm in the late 1980s.
This discovery challenged a long-standing dogma in neuroscience.

Neurogenesis in adult birds and mammals


In adult birds, neurogenesis occurs in:

Song nuclei

Hippocampus

These neurons were proposed to support:

Seasonal song learning

Memory for food cache locations

Adult neurogenesis is linked to learning and memory.

In the late 1990s, adult neurogenesis was also demonstrated
in adult mammals, including humans.
However, it occurs only in specific brain regions.


In adult mammals, neurogenesis occurs mainly in:

The dentate gyrus of the hippocampus

There is no clear evidence for neurogenesis in:

Neocortical areas

Adult neurogenesis is spatially restricted.

Estimating neuron birth in humans

By measuring radioactivity in post-mortem hippocampal tissue:

About 700 new neurons per day are generated

Most die by apoptosis

Some integrate into hippocampal circuits

Approximately 1.75% of dentate gyrus granule cells
are renewed each year.

text:
What is hippocampal neurogenesis for?


After decades of research:

Evidence is abundant

Results are sometimes conflicting

No definitive consensus exists

Several functional hypotheses have been proposed.

Hypothesis 1: pattern separation
Pattern separation allows similar experiences
to be stored as distinct memories.
Pattern separation enables:

Precise encoding of spatial context

Precise encoding of temporal context








Hypothesis 2: memory consolidation
Proposes that neurogenesis supports
systems-level memory consolidation.
Early after learning:

The hippocampus is active

The cortex is relatively silent

Weeks later:

Cortical regions support memory retrieval

Hippocampal involvement decreases

Memories are transferred.

Neurogenesis and pattern separation


Two events may partially overlap:

Event 1: at my cousin’s house, during summer (A)
Event 2: at my aunt’s house, during fall (B)

Good pattern separation allows these events
to be stored as separate memory traces.

The dentate gyrus is thought to:

Separate overlapping contextual representations

Encode temporal context

Adult-born neurons may provide a timestamp for memories.

Ways to increase neurogenesis


Environmental enrichment and physical exercise:

Enhance hippocampal synaptic plasticity

Increase hippocampal neurogenesis

These effects occur even in older animals.

In humans, aerobic exercise:

Increases blood flow in the hippocampus

Especially in the dentate gyrus

This increase correlates with memory performance.

What is Resilience


The term resilience originally comes from metallurgy.

It refers to the ability of a material
to resist forces applied to it without breaking.

In this sense, resilience is the opposite of fragility.


In psychology, resilience does not mean simply resisting damage.
Resilience is the ability to:

React actively to adverse or traumatic events

Reorganize one’s life in a positive way

Continue developing despite difficulties

Resilience involves adaptation, not endurance alone.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The Kauai longitudinal study


The concept of resilience entered psychology through
a landmark longitudinal study.
Werner (1993) followed the entire cohort of children
born in 1955 on the island of Kauai (about 700 individuals for more than 40 years).

About 1/3 of these children were exposed to:

Social disadvantage

Family instability

Environmental stress

As a group, this population showed a higher incidence
of psychological distress.



Despite high risk exposure:

One third of these children developed normally

They formed stable relationships

Showed good work performance

Demonstrated sociability and altruism

These individuals were defined as resilient.


What differentiated resilient individuals
from those who succumbed to early adversity?

From risk to protection


Possible factors included:

Genetics

Life experiences

Protective environmental factors


These findings shifted research focus:
From identifying risk factors
to identifying protective factors.
The question became:
How does the brain adapt successfully to adversity?








To study mechanisms of resilience,
animal models are essential.
One widely used model is social defeat stress.

Resilience as an active process



Resilience is not simply the absence of pathology. It involves active and adaptive processes. These include specific molecular and circuit-level changes.


Resilience involves both:

Passive resilience
Absence of maladaptive molecular responses
seen in vulnerable individuals
Active resilience
Presence of adaptive plastic changes
seen only in resilient individuals





Both forms of resilience depend on neuroplasticity.
Plastic changes allow the brain to:

Adjust stress responses

Reorganize circuits

Maintain functional behavior

Resilience is biologically implemented.

Genetic factors and behavior


Understanding how genetic factors contribute
to behavior and its disorders is a central problem in neuroscience.

Caspi et al. (2006) described three main approaches
to study this relationship:

Gene-to-disorder approach

Endophenotype-to-disorder approach

Gene–environment interaction approach

Gene-to-disorder


The gene-to-disorder approach assumes:

A direct, linear relationship between genes and disorders

Genes are the primary cause of disorders


This approach used:

Linkage analysis

Association studies

It searched for correlations between:

Psychiatric diagnoses

Individual differences in DNA sequence

Endophenotype-to-disorder


The endophenotype-to-disorder approach introduced
intermediate phenotypes.

Endophenotypes are heritable biological traits associated with disorders.


They can be:

Physiological

Biochemical

Anatomical

Example: macrocephaly or immune alterations in ASD.



This approach assumes that:

Endophenotypes have clearer genetic bases

Genes exert stronger effects on intermediate traits
than on complex diagnoses

Gene–environment interaction (G × E)


The gene–environment interaction (G × E) approach
explicitly includes environmental factors.

The G × E approach assumes that:

Environmental risk factors can contribute to disorders

Genotype modulates susceptibility to these factors

Genes influence sensitivity to the environment.



According to the G × E framework:

There may be no gene-behavior association
in the absence of environmental stressors
There may be no environmental effect
without genetic susceptibility

Risk emerges from their interaction.

text:
Genes as risk factors


In this view:

Genes are not causative

They increase the probability of developing a disorder

Only under specific environmental conditions.

Genetic and environmental factors:

Are both risk factors

Act together

Increase vulnerability when combined

Exposure does not guarantee pathology.



Genes:

Define neural circuit potential

Also define limits of environmental influence

The environment:

Acts on genetic circuits

Shapes them toward maturity




Donald Hebb summarized this relationship clearly. Asked whether genes or environment matter more, he replied: Is the height or the width more important to calculate the area of a rectangle?
